item.title: Using SVG
item.description:
I went to a conference recently where one of the speakers talked about using SVGs. I asked a few of my fellow front-enders there if they used SVGs and everyone said, “Not really.”

Not really?

SVGs have some incredible, totally unique features, like small, efficient file sizes (especially when you consider it scales to any size) that compress well; crystal clarity at any size, on any device, including retina devices; and stylability via CSS.

So you might be thinking, “Okay but I bet it doesn’t work in every browser.” Actually…

It’s supported in every major browser (IE 9+) and has been for quite a while. If you have to go IE 8 and below or Android 2.3 and below, you can use some pretty simple fallbacks or something like SVG for Everybody.

“Well then it’s probably more difficult to use.”

Nay, I say! You can use it exactly like any other image type:

<img src=“image.svg”>

or 

.thing {
    background: url(image.svg);
}

That works just like you’d expect. I’ll go into more advanced usage in a minute.

“Yeah, but SVGs will never replace raster images.”

That is right in some cases, of course. You can’t make a photograph using SVG, for instance. SVGs are good for things like icons, illustrations, logos, charts, etc. which are a lot of what we do on the web. In fact, SVGs were actually designed for the web.

Making SVGs to use on the web

Open an SVG in a text editor and you’ll see lines of code that look like HTML. If you’re a math/geometry genius you can learn to how make SVGs with code if you want, but I’m not, so I use Illustrator.

You can make an SVG out of anything that’s vector (.ai, .eps, .pdf, .somethingelse). Just put it in Illustrator or Sketch and “save as” an SVG.

You can also run the file through image optimization to reduce the size even more and clean things up. I use Gulp, so I just use the imagemin plugin for all images, including SVGs. Or, you can use something like SVG Editor.

IcoMoon is golden for working with SVGs, especially if you’re making something like a set of icons. You can drag and drop your own SVGs into the tool or use theirs. It’ll create an SVG sprite, and even give you an example of how to use it in HTML.

Inline SVGs

There’s nothing wrong with using the HTML image tag, but you can also make use of “inline” SVGs.

Since SVGs are just code, you can actually take that code and place it right into your HTML document. Open the SVG in a text editor, copy the code you see, and paste that code where you want the SVG to show up.

Why would you want to do this? There’s a couple cool things about inline SVGs: One of the biggest things for me is that you get the exact same image except there’s no additional HTTP request. Performance happiness.

Another thing is that you can define the SVG once and then use it anywhere else again without pasting the same block code (or just use IcoMoon to automate that). That’s so much better than an icon font.

A lot of improved animations and control come with inline SVGs, too, like the fact that you can target precise pieces of the image with CSS.
